history.content:
Thanks for the comments, and sorry for the confusion.  I'll try to re-do that slide, but probably not in time for you guys.  

The point of logn is that is what the max load will be for this simple scheme which corresponds to standard hashing.  The load of a bin is the # of balls assigned to it.  And the max load is the max over bins of the load, so it's the maximum # of balls in any bin.

children.subject: You could maybe add some clarifying notes in the short term (since re-recording would be more involved).

history.content:
The probabilities are confusing.

First is asks the probability of putting all balls in a particular bin. That is: 1/N

Then it asks what the probability that logN balls end up in a particular bin. That is (1/N)^logN

Then it asks the probability that a particular bin gets at least LogN load. (Not sure what motivates this.. seems arbitrary)

Then it asks the probability that the Max load in at least LogN.
(I'm not really sure what that means.. )

I'm confused by all these probabilities.

Also, why LogN? Whats the magic of the LogN threshold?
history.subject: Balls into Bins: Probabilities
